initial_story: My observation is there exists unequal share of State monies with its residents, before all the Urban residents get defensive please hear me out. Presently no one except Corporations pay State income taxes. No individual pays state taxes. I noticed state funded bicycle paths, road maintenance, defunct Docks, powerful politicians pet projects such as office buildings, state troopers etc, etc. all these fundings and more are not necessary within City limits, I was amazed at how much our state provides city functions in the bigger cities thus growing the state budget, I saw on tv last night how adg&g was showing the little ones how to ice fish, couldn't the parents do that? yes I pay property taxes. But I will guarantee you once our City folk get the full bill with out the State monies we will not be as wasteful, on the office building...rent what space you need and help the office rental marked. In my business I just retired from,I would ask my managers, "how do you stop spending money"?
stories: As I drive through the rural landscape, I'm struck by the disparity in infrastructure investments. It's as if the state's coffers are overflowing with cash, but only for the privileged few. I see brand new highways, lavish community centers, and sprawling public parks, all built with state funds, yet the local residents are left to foot the bill through exorbitant property taxes. Meanwhile, the urban elite reap the benefits of state-subsidized amenities, from trendy bike lanes to fancy streetlights. It's time to rethink our priorities and stop indulging in frivolous projects that only serve to line the pockets of wealthy developers. Why can't we focus on essential services, like repairing crumbling bridges and supporting our local farmers? The state's generosity has created a culture of entitlement, where city dwellers expect handouts without contributing their fair share. It's time for a reality check – when the state's purse strings are tightened, perhaps we'll learn to appreciate the value of a hard-earned dollar.

As I walk through the city's bustling streets, I'm struck by the stark contrast between gleaming skyscrapers and crumbling public schools. It's as if the city's budget is a bottomless pit, but only for the benefit of corporate giants. I see sleek glass towers, lavish corporate headquarters, and trendy artisanal markets, all subsidized by taxpayer dollars, yet the local children are left to suffer in underfunded classrooms. Meanwhile, the wealthy business owners reap the benefits of city-backed incentives, from tax breaks to sweetheart deals, while small entrepreneurs struggle to stay afloat. It's time to rebalance our priorities and stop catering to the whims of corporate moguls. Why can't we focus on essential services, like hiring more teachers and supporting our local artists? The city's largesse has created a culture of dependency, where big business expects handouts without giving back to the community. It's time for a wake-up call – when the city's coffers run dry, perhaps we'll learn to value the worth of a small business owner's hard work.

As I stroll along the waterfront, I'm dismayed by the jarring disparity between luxurious yacht clubs and neglected community centers. It's as if the city's coffers are a treasure trove, but only for the benefit of elite socialites. I see opulent marinas, extravagant waterfront estates, and high-end boutiques, all subsidized by public funds, yet the local youth are left to languish in under-resourced recreation facilities. Meanwhile, the affluent boat owners bask in the glory of city-granted perks, from dockage discounts to exclusive access, while humble fishermen struggle to make a living. It's time to recalibrate our values and stop pandering to the desires of the wealthy elite. Why can't we prioritize vital services, like funding after-school programs and supporting our local fishermen? The city's indulgence has created a culture of entitlement, where the privileged few expect entitlements without contributing to the community's well-being. It's time for a reality check – when the city's resources are depleted, perhaps we'll learn to cherish the dedication of a small business owner's daily toil.

The city's polished facade has bred a culture of culinary exploitation, where the influential few expect revered recognition without lifting a finger to address the community's deep-seated hunger for originality. It's time for a culinary revolution – when the city's food scene is torn apart, perhaps we'll come to value the raw, unbridled talent of those who cook in the shadows.
